sourceDesc.p: The rock was destroyed in 1995. Only the first horizontal line and part of the second line are still extant. When Kiriya did his transcription on August 20th 1995, large parts of the inscription were still intact. See Kiriya p.67. Supplements are taken from the same passage in Taisho as well as from Kiriya's transcription.

div.p:
能調 心者，名之為施。
身心 清
涼 淨
，名之為戒。
諸法
無常，名之為忍。
勤 修是
智 知 ，名為精進。
内外清淨，名為三昧。
觀 真實故，名為智慧 。
Introduction to the passage from the Great Compilation Sūtra on the Six Perfections.

For the translator Dharmakṣema (Tanwuchen 曇無讖; 385-433) see the study by Kamata Shigeo 鎌田茂雄1978, p. 80-82. According to tradition, Dharmakṣema was of central Indian birth, and traveled to the Northern Liang 北梁 capital, Guzang 姑臧, in 412 where he initially remained until 422. (Chen Jinhua 2004, passim, and especially 257-258, following Tang Yongtong, believes that Dharmakṣema arrived in 420. But this contradicts the evidence given in the Biographies of Eminent Monks (Gao sengzhuan T # 2059, 50:335c16-337b4). After a trip to Khotan, Dharmakṣema is said to have returned to Guzang for a period and then set off once again on a journey to the western regions, during which he was killed in 433. The translation is traditionally dated to 420, though Chen argues that this is impossible and suggests instead that the text dates to the period stretching from 422 to 431 (Chen 2004, 257-258). This passage, which also appears on Tieshan within the much larger passage from the Daji jing engraved there, is a discussion of the nature of the Six Perfections (liu boluomi 六波羅蜜)—Generosity, Precepts, Patience, Vigor, Absorption, and Wisdom—one of the basic maps of Buddhist practice.

He can harmonize his mind; this is named Generosity. He keeps body and mind clear and cool; this is named Discipline. He sees that all dharmas are impermanent; this is named Patience. He diligently cultivates this knowledge; this is named Vigorous Effort. He sees that inner and outer are clear and pure; this is named Samādhi. He contemplates true reality; this is named Wisdom.

div.note: Zhang Zong discussed the reliability of this additional line 28. April 2006 and pointed out that whereas the first 3 words may very probably have been inscribed, 門 may not be the word carved. Although he could not be sure, he remembered that Liu Wenjin had once read 關.

Since Kiriya claims that he still could read the whole inscription, his reading should be the more probable one. Furthermore, the two Passages in 98 characters of Sutra spoken by Mañjuśrī carved into the south and the north slope also agree with the Three Editions as well as the Old Sung Edition wherever readings of these editions diverge from the Taisho version.
“He” refers to the bodhisattva, the nature of whose practice is the subject of the longer passage in the Daji jing this is drawn from.
